A Metanalysis of Beaver Translocation Methods to Inform Establishment Success and Beaver Management Policy Chapter 1 About 1.1 Introduction

A Metanalysis of Beaver Translocation Methods to Inform Establishment Success and Beaver Management Policy Molly Alves 2023-04-19 Chapter 1 About This book has been prepared for the Reproducible Data Science 2023 final assignment and was written in Markdown. 1.1 Introduction Beavers (American, Castor canadensis; Eurasian, Castor fiber) have long been valued for their dense fur and aromatic castor, resulting in their near extirpation from North America and Europe in the late 19th century. Their systematic removal led to a loss of wetland habitat and ecosystem services provided by the beaver’s damming activity. Modern harvest restrictions have enabled their recovery in some areas; however, there are many barriers to natural recolonization, whether anthropogenic (infrastructure, stream channelization), ecological (climate impacts to seasonal flow and vegetative communities), or political (misclassification and social carrying capacity). Today, beaver translocation has become a popular management strategy for habitat restoration, fire abatement, and a widely accepted method of nature-based restoration in rewilding efforts. There are, however, vast differences in the ways in which beaver translocation programs monitor translocated beavers in terms of release site selection and post-translocation monitoring, how they define translocation success, and the policies that guide translocation activities. My thesis aims to synthesize available information by (1) accumulating and analyzing beaver translocation methodology data from current and past translocations; and (2) developing a database of existing beaver management policies where beaver translocation is occurring. By analyzing the cumulative data from all contributing beaver translocation projects, I propose to create guiding principles for humane and successful beaver translocation. Combining this synthesis, with an accessible database on policies, will allow future translocation projects to rapidly identify best practices for their geographic region.
Chapter 2 Project Organization 2.1 Load Raw Data from Survey

Chapter 2 Project Organization For my final semester project, I will be establishing a database that will enable me to manage, clean, and code my incoming data for eventual import into R for meta-analysis. The Google Forms Survey was lauched two weeks ago. So far, I have received 22 responses. I will use this as test data and manipulate it to fit my database structure. 2.1 Load Raw Data from Survey RawData_test <- readxl::read_excel ("~/MASTERS/Bookdown/GoogleFormRespTEST.xlsx") RawData_test ## # A tibble: 22 × 110 ## Timestamp Email A…¹ What …² What …³ What …⁴ If no…⁵ What …⁶ What …⁷ ## <dttm> <chr> <chr> <chr> <chr> <chr> <chr> <chr> ## 1 2023-03-28 07:39:33 travis.c… Travis… Habita… State/… NA WY Gam… NA ## 2 2022-11-29 10:12:27 jerry.al… Gerard… Biolog… State n/a Wyomin… <NA> ## 3 2023-03-24 14:14:43 dcollins… Dylan … Assist… Tribal <NA> The Tu… Tulali… ## 4 2023-03-28 08:33:57 charnna@… Charnn… Execut… Non-pr… 501c3 Scott … N/A ## 5 2023-03-28 08:40:16 rschicks… Rachel… Presid… Non-pr… fiscal… Illino… n/a ## 6 2023-03-28 09:42:33 matt.pro… Matt P… Region… State/… <NA> Idaho … Upper … ## 7 2023-03-28 11:44:46 loren.ta… Loren … Wildli… Part-t… <NA> Beaver… NA ## 8 2023-03-28 15:55:18 caristuc… Caroli… Gradua… UC Dav… <NA> UC Dav… NA ## 9 2023-03-29 08:51:16 sahill@u… Shane … Habita… State/… <NA> Utah D… Northe… ## 10 2023-03-29 10:29:14 teresagr… Teresa… Wildli… State/… <NA> Utah D… Southe… ## # … with 12 more rows, 102 more variables: ## # `Are you the project lead for the beaver translocations?` <chr>, ## # `If no, or co-lead, who is the project lead/co-lead?` <chr>, ## # `Where is your project located (ex: name of City, County, State, Province, Country, Watershed, etc...)?` <chr>, ## # `Does your project employ seasonal or permanent staff (check all that apply)?` <chr>, ## # `What is the population status of beavers in your area?` <chr>, ## # `Does your jurisdiction allow for the translocation of beavers?` <chr>, …
Chapter 3 Database Structure 3.1 Database Creation 3.2 Tables 3.3 Relational Database Diagram

Chapter 3 Database Structure The package DBI was used to create the database and tables. I chose this directory structure so that it is nested in my root directory for easy import into R and for version tracking with Git. For organizational purposes, I placed it in my MASTERS folder, under the folder MetaAnalysis so that all files associated with my degree and proposed meta-analysis are in one, easy to locate folder. I chose to add folders for Code, Data, Figures, Manuscripts, README, and Results at your recommendation so that I can track and version control all incoming data, code that is created, and eventual Figures, Results, and Manuscripts that are developed from the eventual analysis. The README folder will track all inputs to these folders as my metadata. The MetaAnalysis folder can then be zipped and shared at the conclusion of the study for anyone that may want to replicate my methods. 3.1 Database Creation metabeaver_db <- dbConnect(RSQLite::SQLite(), "../../MASTERS/MetaAnalysis/Data/metabeaver.db") 3.2 Tables responses, projects, questions, answers_text, answers_mc, answers_ls, answers_ca. 3.2.1 responses - This table will contain all responses submitted to the Google Forms survey and will contact columns for response ID (resp_id) and project ID (proj_id). Response IDs will be generated electronically based on the order of survey submission and each project will be manually assigned a unique character code to distinguish it among others. dbExecute(metabeaver_db, "CREATE TABLE responses ( resp_id varchar (5) NOT NULL PRIMARY KEY, FOREIGN KEY(proj_id) REFERENCES projects(proj_id) );") 3.2.2 projects - This table will contain information about all respondents projects and contact information and will contain columns for proj_id, proj_email, proj_name, proj_agency, proj_501c3, proj_called, proj_lead, proj_lead_alt, and proj_location. The proj_id column will serve as the foreign key linking this table to the Responses table. dbExecute(metabeaver_db, "CREATE TABLE projects ( proj_id varchar(5) PRIMARY KEY proj_email text, proj_name text, proj_agency varchar (15) CHECK (proj_agency IN ('State', 'Federal', 'Tribal', 'Non Profit', 'For Profit')), proj_501c3 varchar (15) CHECK (proj_501c3 IN ('501c3', 'fiscal sponsor')), proj_called text, proj_lead varchar (5) CHECK (proj_lead IN ('yes', 'no')), proj_lead_alt text, proj_location text );") 3.2.3 questions -This table will contain all of the questions and type of questions that will be asked in the Google Forms survey and will contain columns for quest_id, quest_type, and questions. dbExecute(metabeaver_db, "CREATE TABLE questions ( quest_id varchar text PRIMARY KEY questions text, quest_type varchar (5) CHECK (quest_type IN ('text', 'mc', 'ls', 'ca')), );") 3.2.4 answers_text -This table will contain all answers to short and long answer questions and will contain columns for text_id, answer, resp_id, and quest_id. The resp_id and quest_id columns will serve as foregin keys linking this table to the Responses and Questions tables. dbExecute(metabeaver_db, "CREATE TABLE answers_text ( text_id text PRIMARY KEY, answer text, FOREIGN KEY(resp_id) REFERENCES responses(resp_id) FOREIGN KEY(quest_id) REFERENCES questions(quest_id) );") 3.2.5 answers-mc -This table will contain all answers to multiple choice questions and will contain columns for mc_id, answer, resp_id, and quest_id. The resp_id and quest_id columns will serve as foregin keys linking this table to the Responses and Questions tables. dbExecute(metabeaver_db, "CREATE TABLE answers_mc ( mc_id text PRIMARY KEY, answer text, FOREIGN KEY(resp_id) REFERENCES responses(resp_id) FOREIGN KEY(quest_id) REFERENCES questions(quest_id) );") 3.2.6 answers_ls -This table will contain all answers to linear scale questions and will contain columns for ls_id, answer, resp_id, and quest_id. The resp_id and quest_id columns will serve as foregin keys linking this table to the Responses and Questions tables. dbExecute(metabeaver_db, "CREATE TABLE answers_ls ( ls_id text PRIMARY KEY, answer text, FOREIGN KEY(resp_id) REFERENCES responses(resp_id) FOREIGN KEY(quest_id) REFERENCES questions(quest_id) );") 3.2.7 answers_ca -This table will contain all answers to check all that apply questions and will contain columns for ca_id, answer_1, answer_2, answer_3, answer_4, answer_5, resp_id, and quest_id. The resp_id and quest_id columns will serve as foregin keys linking this table to the Responses and Questions tables. dbExecute(metabeaver_db, "CREATE TABLE answers_ca ( ca_id text PRIMARY KEY, answer text, FOREIGN KEY(resp_id) REFERENCES responses(resp_id) FOREIGN KEY(quest_id) REFERENCES questions(quest_id) );") 3.3 Relational Database Diagram Figure 3.1: Relational Database Diagram
